description: From Middle English legitimat, legytymat, from Medieval Latin lēgitimatus, perfect passive participle of Latin lēgitimō (“make legal”), from Latin lēgitimus (“lawful”), originally "fixed by law, in line with the law," from Latin lēx (“law”). Originally "lawfully begotten".
The verb was derived from the adjective by conversion.

adjectives.description: legitimate (comparative more legitimate, superlative most legitimate)

entries.meaning: In accordance with the law or established legal forms and requirements.
Conforming to known principles, or established or accepted rules or standards; valid.
examples: legitimate reasoning; a legitimate standard or method
legitimate poems of Chaucer; legitimate inscriptions

entries.meaning: Lawfully begotten, i.e., born to a legally married couple. [from mid-14th c.]
Belonging or relating to the legitimate theater.
A person born to a legally married couple.

verbs.description: legitimate (third-person singular simple present legitimates, present participle legitimating, simple past and past participle legitimated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make legitimate, lawful, or valid; especially, to put in the position or state of a legitimate person before the law, by legal means. [from 1590]
